messages.text:
Hello everyone!

I’m Nathan, I’m a PhD student studying crowdsourcing/hybrid intelligence/philosophy of statistics at the Institute for Data Science & Artificial Intelligence at the University of Manchester. I’m a fairly proficient R user but have been slowly falling in love with Julia during lockdown!

I’m looking to move more of my research workflow over to Julia and eventually some of my teaching work too.
I’m particularly interested in using Julia as a GIS and learning how to develop packages for applications that don’t currently exist in Julia (such as a package for structural equation modelling, equivalent to what lavaan offers in R, and a package for multiverse/specification curve analyses).

elements.text:
Hello everyone!

I’m Nathan, I’m a PhD student studying crowdsourcing/hybrid intelligence/philosophy of statistics at the Institute for Data Science & Artificial Intelligence at the University of Manchester. I’m a fairly proficient R user but have been slowly falling in love with Julia during lockdown!

I’m looking to move more of my research workflow over to Julia and eventually some of my teaching work too.
I’m particularly interested in using Julia as a GIS and learning how to develop packages for applications that don’t currently exist in Julia (such as a package for structural equation modelling, equivalent to what lavaan offers in R, and a package for multiverse/specification curve analyses).

messages.text:
Hello everyone,
I'm Dodd (he/him), a postdoc working on a mix of topics in nonlinear optics, integrated photonics and Raman spectroscopy in the EECS dept. at MIT. I've been coming up to speed on Julia for the past several months and developing code for PDE-constrained optimization ("inverse design") of waveguides for short laser pulses. Migrating from using python to control compiled PDE solver libraries has been surprisingly approachable thanks to all of the great ongoing work in the Julia community and is already proving useful for my research. I am excited to join and hopefully contribute to the ecosystem.
I am currently focused on automatic differentiation applied to eigenmode solutions of parameterized PDEs (just the Helmholtz equation for now), Other relevant buzzwords include "adjoint method" and "matrix-free"/"implicit" operators. Please feel free to reach out if you have overlapping interests and would like to chat. I look forward to learning from/with you all.

elements.text:
Hello everyone,
I'm Dodd (he/him), a postdoc working on a mix of topics in nonlinear optics, integrated photonics and Raman spectroscopy in the EECS dept. at MIT. I've been coming up to speed on Julia for the past several months and developing code for PDE-constrained optimization ("inverse design") of waveguides for short laser pulses. Migrating from using python to control compiled PDE solver libraries has been surprisingly approachable thanks to all of the great ongoing work in the Julia community and is already proving useful for my research. I am excited to join and hopefully contribute to the ecosystem.
I am currently focused on automatic differentiation applied to eigenmode solutions of parameterized PDEs (just the Helmholtz equation for now), Other relevant buzzwords include "adjoint method" and "matrix-free"/"implicit" operators. Please feel free to reach out if you have overlapping interests and would like to chat. I look forward to learning from/with you all.

messages.text:
Hello,
I am an engineer doing sensor characterization and calibrations for a manufacturing company in Canada.
I started using Julia in 2017 to avoid writing complex wrappers in python. Had some fights with management over the years over it's use, and it looks like 2021 is the year where it's usage is finally accepted by management.

messages.text:
Hi everyone :wave:
I’m a 2nd year PhD student and I decided that the moment has come for me to learn Julia :smile:
What are the best resources you would suggest to get into the field (not too basic however, I’ve been programming –scientific programming, and mostly Python– for years now)?
I found the course _Introduction to Computational Thinking_ by MIT which uses Julia and looks great, do you suggest it? <https://computationalthinking.mit.edu/Spring21/>
Have any other valuable resource?

Thanks, and have a great week! :party_parrot:

messages.text: Hey, I'm a data scientist and I'm taking Julia for a ride, especially trying out Turing.jl and how it compares with PyMC3 and Stan! So far I really love the documentation and examples, though I find it always a little difficult to get into the syntax of a new language (after 10+ years of Python, 1 year of R). It does seem to have a relatively low learning curve, which is great :wink:

messages.text:
Hello guys. I am an associate professor of Smart Cities and Urban Planning at Universidade Nove de Julho located in São Paulo Brazil. I currently advise PhD candidates and also teach graduates and undergraduates in Stats, Bayesian Stats, Machine Learning, Deep Learning. My main focus (and passion) is probabilistic languages and Bayesian Statistics. I currently contribute to Stan and I am also looking to help in turing.

I've been dabbling with Julia for 2 years now. From 2021 onwards I realized that Julia is the future of scientific computing and everything new I am doing it in Julia with research, classes, students and candidates.

Such a welcoming community. I would like to express my deepest gratitude and I am here to contribute and help as much as I can.

messages.text: Hi! I'm Arif. I am a postdoc at ICTS-TIFR, India where I work on gravitational wave astrophysics and waveform modeling using numerical relativity. I am a member of the LIGO-VIRGO collaboration and also a member of the Simulating eXtreme Spacetime (SXS) collaboration. I am starting to learn more about Julia by using it as the primary language for a course on compact objects <https://github.com/md-arif-shaikh/Physics-Of-Compact-Objects>. Looking forward to enhance my Julia knowledge further.

messages.text:
Hey there!! I am a 3rd year college undergraduate interested in Data Science, ML, DL etc. particularly Reinforcement learning.

I am someone who is happy to learn something new everyday and so far my learning experience in this background has been incredible Looking forward to learn more on my interests and develop some expertise. I am relatively new to Julia but have some familiarity in other frameworks but the more I seem to venture into the language the more I seem to fall in love with it.

I am looking for contributing to open source and I really feel that this might be a great place to start. If anyone could point to where I could start, that would be really helpful.

messages.text:
Hello all!  Jacob Vaverka here.  I work at General Motors on a team that brings FOSS to High Performance Computing.  My main work focus is in CFD and CAE workflows.  I 'm also working toward a masters degree in Applied & Computational Math.  This program is where I was introduced to Julia about 2 years ago.  Now I use Julia for all sorts of personal projects (usually deployed via web as Heroku apps).  BUT I'd really love to get involved with growing Julia's capabilities in enterprise CAE.

On a personal note I love hiking, yoga, and movies.  Excited to be here :nerd_face: feel free to <https://vaverka.gitlab.io/|check out my site> (_*built using Franklin*_) to learn more.

messages.text: Hola all! :wave: I'm Aadhitya from India. I'm a sophomore pursuing IT at Anna University, Chennai. Well, so far my interests are on Machine Learning, NLP, Web Development. For a year, I've been using Tensorflow as my primary tool, but when I came across Julia through the web and from my peers, I started to research on it. A language that's fast as C++ and statistical as Python & R ?? I can't believe it's true! That's the main reason I wanted to learn Julia and yep still in progress xD. After learning it, I may want to contribute to it as well! :wink: :nerd_face:

Hello All. I'm Thadryan. I do and teach computational bio - mostly biostats related to heart failure studies and visualization apps. I'm a Python fan and begrudging R user learning Julia out of curiosity and because I've been burned by factors one too many times!:v::skin-tone-2:

elements.text: Hello All. I'm Thadryan. I do and teach computational bio - mostly biostats related to heart failure studies and visualization apps. I'm a Python fan and begrudging R user learning Julia out of curiosity and because I've been burned by factors one too many times!

messages.text:
:slightly_smiling_face:Hello everyone! I'm Omar from Mexico. Self-taught R user and Python novice (Just web scraping). To be honest, I have seen a lot of information of why Julia is better than R&Python, so I am really interested in learning this language.

In addition, I was about to create a static page in R (Distill Rstudio) but then I started seeing everything Julia has ahead and even saw that with Franklin you can create a page! (Dunno how to do it at the moment but anyways I will figure it out)

Having this on the table, I am anxious to contribute to the community of Julia as much as possible :clap:

P.S. I was wondering if there is a channel regarding Julia Jobs/vacancies (Maybe instead of focusing in R&Python I should give a try to Full-Julia) :ok_hand:

elements.text:
Hello everyone! I'm Omar from Mexico. Self-taught R user and Python novice (Just web scraping). To be honest, I have seen a lot of information of why Julia is better than R&Python, so I am really interested in learning this language.

In addition, I was about to create a static page in R (Distill Rstudio) but then I started seeing everything Julia has ahead and even saw that with Franklin you can create a page! (Dunno how to do it at the moment but anyways I will figure it out)

Having this on the table, I am anxious to contribute to the community of Julia as much as possible
P.S. I was wondering if there is a channel regarding Julia Jobs/vacancies (Maybe instead of focusing in R&Python I should give a try to Full-Julia)

messages.text:
Hi!
I am Michele from Italy. I am junior research assistant pursuing my MSc in Computer Science in Milan.  I have stepped into Julia last year during an internship in Antwerp. This event quickly arose my interest in HPC and Scientific Computing :slightly_smiling_face:
I am eager to join the effort of the community :slightly_smiling_face: and contribute to the development of the julia environment.
I might consider Gsoc, but I haven't decided yet.
Cheers

messages.text:
Hi there.
Layne Sadler from Boston.
• Recently wrote the AIQC framework (<http://aiqc.readthedocs.io|aiqc.readthedocs.io>) to drive adoption of deep learning in open science, and to make deep learning reproducible.
• Career product manager - most recently a biotech in genomics working on national biobanks w pharma.
• Ran the Jupyter 2021 survey.
• Love modeling nature as graph data structures.
Wondering if JuliaComputing is building out product management in Boston?

Hi,
I'm Fabian doing a PhD on forest soil hydrology at WSL/ETHZ in Switzerland. Using data from long term monitoring plots and additionally stable isotopes I will use Bayesian parameter estimation of porous flow and transport model parameters in <https://github.com/fabern/LWFBrook90.jl|LWFBrook.jl>.

messages.text:
Hello everyone! I am a final-year, CS and data science double-major undergraduate at HKUST. Nice to meet you all. I am looking forward to participating in jsoc!

I have some experience in projects and research in NLP (e.g. text generation based on BERT) and ML (e.g. fake news detection with a proposed GNN variant) (also 4 relevant courseworks, including Advanced AI (A+)). I've found some reletated projects that I'm interested in, so I am learning Julia!

messages.text:
Hey everyone!

I'm a data scientist (cto at a series A fintech startup in Southeast Asia) who is mainly coming from R applied to finance. I'm interested in Julia mainly to solve the two language problem in our data work, and to see if the language can be useful outside of scientific computing like web app backends.

I'm documenting my findings in this Julia package so I can synthesize them later: <https://github.com/tjpalanca/LearningJulia.jl>

Thanks for the great resources and so far welcoming community!

messages.text: Hi everyone, I’m Gideon. I’m a PhD a student in machine learning at ETH Zurich where I’ve been working on convex optimization for ML, such as Frank-Wolfe as well as variational inference. I’ve been following the Julia project for some time now and am always looking for excuses to get involved. I’ve recently been getting excited about combining machine learning with more traditional modelling approaches (PDEs). The DifferentialEquations package seems at the forefront and I hope to get invovled.

messages.text: Hello! I am a PhD candidate in Applied Math at the University of Waterloo (Canada), my grad work so far has been on models of ecological systems, and of course lately modelling the pandemic. I found Julia in 2019 when I was working with bifurcations in systems of SDEs and there were few good SDE solvers outside of DifferentialEquations.jl. Since then, I have rewritten all my model code in Julia. I've been around here a while already, and have met some great people so far ^_^.
